Title: O MARE vai à escola
Description: Educational program aimed at raising awareness on ocean-related topics - marine biodiversity, aquatic organisms adaptation, tropic webs, conservation, exploration and integrated management of marine resources, the Humanity's role in sustainable development -  to bring the school public closer to scientific research. Key is the use of fun, interactive and creative strategies in informal contexts, such as hands-on activities, laboratory activities, interactive games, mystery boxes, guided tours, storytelling.

Title: Projecto 19
Description:
Projecto 19 (P19) invites high school students to convert ocean research papers into outreach activities and artistic performances, with resultig formats ranging from tv news reports, social media campaigns, videos, stock motion animations, field trips, stakeholders’ meetings, theatre plays, songs, dance, street art, among others.
P19 aims to promote the search and use of reliable up-to-date scientific information by teenagers, thereby contributing to eradicate negationism and misinformation.

Title: Know, think, act (1.14)
Description: Students learn about the sources and dangers of marine pollution, particularly plastic debris. Working in groups, they research a specific type of marine litter and create a campaign to raise awareness and encourage prevention. The best campaign is chosen for implementation.

Title: The waves (1.1)
Description: Students explore the ocean's connection to people and culture through various artistic expressions (text, song, video, drawing) inspired by authors like Woolf and real-life stories. The final presentations spark discussion on ocean-culture relationships and artistic communication.

Title: The role of international legislation to protect the high seas (1.2)
Description: Students delve into maritime zones and ocean resource use. Researching their own countries' dependence on the sea, they participate in mock negotiations, representing different countries and advocating for responsible practices.

Title: Exploring the energy potential of the Ocean (1.3)
Description: This activity focuses on understanding the different uses of the ocean (fishing, conservation, tourism) and potential conflicts. Students take on the roles of ocean users, brainstorm synergies and conflicts, and design solutions for sustainable ocean management.

Title: Ocean currents and ocean drifters (1.4)
Description: Students explore the impact of temperature on water flow and learn about major ocean currents. They create models and predict water movement. This activity culminates in tracking a real-life mini-boat navigating ocean currents.

Title: Build a buoy (1.5)
Description: Working in teams, students apply engineering principles to design and build buoyant buoys using provided materials. They compete to create the most effective design based on specific criteria.

Title: How does ocean acidification occur? (1.6)
Description: Students simulate the process of ocean acidification and observe its effects on marine organisms, highlighting the connection between CO2 emissions and ocean health. They discuss the human connection to this issue and potential solutions.

Title: Let’s go fishing (1.7)
Description: Through a hands-on simulation, students experience the consequences of unregulated fishing and explore the importance of sustainable fishing practices for maintaining fish populations and healthy ecosystems.

Title: Integrated Multi-Trophic Aquaculture (IMTA) (1.8)
Description: Students build a model simulating integrated multi-trophic aquaculture (IMTA), a system that reduces waste and increases productivity. This activity encourages discussion about sustainable aquaculture practices.

Title: Let’s explore the deep sea (1.9)
Description: Students work in groups to plan an oceanographic expedition for exploring a specific resource. They consider logistics, equipment, budget, and environmental impact while aiming for a sustainable and informative mission.

Title: Watershed activity using anadromous fish cherry salmon to understand land-ocean connection (1.10)
Description: Students participate in five yearly activities that highlight the interconnectedness of forests, rivers, and the ocean. They learn about the importance of this connection for ecological health and human well-being.

Title: Eat the right fish (1.11)
Description: This lesson promotes responsible fishing practices by showing the connections between fish consumption, fishing methods, and ocean health. Students participate in three activities: the identification of endangered vs. sustainable fish species, the analysis of fish consumption patterns and their impact, and the role-playing of a food chain disrupted by overfishing.

Title: How deep is the sea? (1.12)
Description: Students delve into the concept of maritime zones by creating a 3D model of an ocean basin. They explore the unique characteristics of different zones (shape, depth, resources) and discuss how humans interact with each area. The final model is presented to the community.

Title: The sea: water that... sustains us! (1.13)
Description: This activity focuses on the fundamental properties of seawater and their influence on ocean circulation and life. Through hands-on experiments, students explore concepts like density, salinity, and buoyancy. They learn how these factors influence ocean currents and the distribution of marine life.
Author, Country: Silvia Merlino, Rosaria Evangelista, Carlo Mantovani, Marinella Abbate, Marco Bianucci

Title: Sea-based materials inventory & Eco-food menu
Description: Lisbon is working with the local BioLab to prototype a community-centered sea-based materials lab. This lab will foster research on novel sea-based biomaterials applications while supporting the creation of a participatory heritage inventory. Additionally, elementary schools and museum canteens will experimentally adopt an experimental eco-food-menu.

Title: Tagus Museum think tank & art-science residencies
Description: Oeiras aims to reposition itself as a beacon for sea-based research by defining and implementing an intergenerational strategy for sea education. This strategy will include an art-science residency project focused on the aquatic ecosystem of the Tagus and a think-tank for the future Tagus Museum.

Title: Ocean Culture Hub & natural-based reef
Description: Malmö is addressing its need for urban development as an opportunity to increase blue biodiversity. For this, a natural-based reef is being developed  in the city's south wharf basin. This nature-culture infrastructure will enable common activities for humans and non-humans in the framework of a long-term platform called "Ocean Culture Hub".

Title: OL Fellowship Program & future foodscape digital tool
Description: Hamburg aims become the European capital of green and digital transformation, with special attention to the ocean. Along this line, the city is developing expertise in eco-gastronomy and curating an Ocean Literacy fellowship program. The core goal is to kick-start a common reflection on the future Hanseatic foodscape, also thanks to an innovative digital prototype on local, food-related data.

Title: Inclusive Digital Storytelling on marine heritage
Description: Genoa is on a mission to promote citizen re-connection to its coastal area. The city plans to adapt MEMEX software for inclusive digital storytelling and engage communities in a sea-people exchange, raising awareness of human-marine ecosystem interdependence and integrating Genoa's historical framework with the sea.

Title: Eco-aware tours led by elders/fishers-driven stories
Description: Venice aims to reconnect people with the Lagoon through a socially-driven urban development plan. To do so the city is investing in senior citizens'and fishers' know-how, by prototyping eco-aware tourism strategies, eco-sustainable fishing practices and regenerative menus.

Title: Participatory MSP  programme
Description: Antwerp aims to find new cross-cutting usages for its transnational territory. The city plans to promote rewilding area prototyping and engage local communities in developing a new identity-based model for the area, strengthening estuarine nature values, making the landscape climate-adaptive, developing agriculture in a nature-inclusive way, and ensuring the port remains the region's economic gateway.

Title: Learning with Water" curriculum module
Description: Rotterdam is on a mission to redefine education with water at its core. The city plans to develop a curriculum based on the 'distributed university' concept, focusing on shared water knowledge and water-citizen-city interdependence. The curriculum will be developed with various bottom-up, activist, cultural, and archival organizations, and will include different learning tracks, such as 'Living with Water'.
